attributes.name: Land use
attributes.description: The total land area required to produce the material. Land impact is calculated using material production and yield data from the global 2010 MAPSPAM and 2010 Gridded Livestock of the World v3 (GLWv3) datasets.

unit.name: hectare per year
unit.description: A unit of count defining the number of units counted in multiples of 100.

metadata.name: Land use
citation: International Food Policy Research Institute, 2019, “Global Spatially-Disaggregated Crop Production Statistics Data for 2010 Version 2.0”, https://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/PRFF8V, Harvard Dataverse, V4

Yu, Q., You, L., Wood-Sichra, U., Ru, Y., et. al. 2020. A cultivated planet in 2010: 2. the global gridded agricultural production maps, Earth Syst. Sci. Data Discuss. https://doi.org/10.5194/essd-2020-11

Gilbert, M., Nicolas, G., Cinardi, G., Van Boeckel, T.P., et. al. 2018. Global distribution data for cattle, buffaloes, horses, sheep, goats, pigs, chickens and ducks in 2010. Scientific data, 5(1), pp.1-11. https://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.227
metadata.description: The total land area required to produce the material. Land impact is calculated using material production and yield data from the global 2010 MAPSPAM and 2010 Gridded Livestock of the World v3 (GLWv3) datasets.

attributes.name: Deforestation risk
attributes.description: Forest loss occurring near material production areas. Deforestation is either calculated using Satelligence models trained to identify transitions from forest to non-forest states in satellite imagery, or using global tree cover loss data from Global Forest Watch.

unit.name: hectare per year
unit.description: A unit of count defining the number of units counted in multiples of 100.

metadata.name: Deforestation risk
citation: Hansen, M. C., P. V. Potapov, R. Moore, M. Hancher, S. A. Turubanova, A. Tyukavina, D. Thau, et al. 2013. “High-Resolution Global Maps of 21st-Century Forest Cover Change.” Science 342 (6160): 850–53. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1244693.
metadata.description: Forest loss occurring near material production areas. Deforestation is either calculated using Satelligence models trained to identify transitions from forest to non-forest states in satellite imagery, or using global tree cover loss data from Global Forest Watch.
metadata.geographic coverage: Global coverage (excluding Antarctica and other Arctic islands).

attributes.name: Climate risk from land use change
attributes.description: The GHG emissions associated with forest loss near agricultural production areas. The general equation for landscape-level impacts is adjusted for the mean annual gross emissions of GHGs associated with forest change from 2001 to 2019.

unit.name: tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent per year
unit.description: Tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent per year

metadata.name: Climate risk
citation: Harris, N.L., Gibbs, D.A., Baccini, A. et al. Global maps of twenty-first century forest carbon fluxes. Nat. Clim. Chang. 11, 234–240 (2021). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41558-020-00976-6
metadata.description: The GHG emissions associated with forest loss near agricultural production areas. The general equation for landscape-level impacts is adjusted for the mean annual gross emissions of GHGs associated with forest change from 2001 to 2019.

attributes.name: Unsustainable water use
attributes.description: The water consumption in regions with a baseline water stress (BWS) ratio of more than 0.4, as identified by Aqueduct. BWS measures the ratio of total water withdrawals to available renewable surface and groundwater supplies.

unit.name: milions of cubic meters per year
unit.description: Millions of cubic meters per year

metadata.name: Unsustainable water use
citation: Hofste, R., S. Kuzma, S. Walker, E.H. Sutanudjaja, et. al. 2019. “Aqueduct 3.0: Updated DecisionRelevant Global Water Risk Indicators.” Technical Note. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available online at: https://www.wri.org/publication/aqueduct-30
metadata.description: The water consumption in regions with a baseline water stress (BWS) ratio of more than 0.4, as identified by Aqueduct. BWS measures the ratio of total water withdrawals to available renewable surface and groundwater supplies.

attributes.name: Water use
attributes.description: The water resources consumed to produce the material. Water consumption impact calculated using product blue water footprint estimates from the period 1996-2005.

unit.name: milions of cubic meters per year
unit.description: Millions of cubic meters per year

metadata.name: Water use
citation: Mekonnen, M.M. & Hoekstra, A.Y. (2011) The green, blue and grey water footprint of crops and derived crop products, Hydrology and Earth System Sciences, 15(5): 1577-1600.
Mekonnen, M.M. & Hoekstra, A.Y. (2012) A global assessment of the water footprint of farm animal products, Ecosystems, 15(3): 401–415.
metadata.description: The water resources consumed to produce the material. Water consumption impact calculated using product blue water footprint estimates from the period 1996-2005.
